articles.headline: U.S. Offers Key Support to Canadian Pipeline
articles.snippet: A State Department report found sufficient environmental safeguards to proceed with a project to carry oil to Oklahoma and the Gulf Coast.
articles.abstract: A State Department report found sufficient environmental safeguards to proceed with a project to carry oil to Oklahoma and the Gulf Coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department gave a crucial green light on Friday to a proposed 1,711-mile pipeline that would carry heavy oil from oil sands in Canada across the Great Plains to terminals in Oklahoma and the Gulf Coast.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Big Asset Sale Near at Bank of America
articles.snippet: A consortium of sovereign wealth funds and private equity firms is in negotiations with bankers, an official briefed on the talks said.
articles.abstract: A consortium of sovereign wealth funds and private equity firms is in negotiations with bankers, an official briefed on the talks said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America is completing plans to sell more than half of its stake in the China Construction Bank in a deal that could raise nearly $10 billion, just a day after Warren E. Buffett invested $5 billion in the beleaguered American financial giant.

articles.headline: For Seamless Transitions, Don’t Look to Hewlett
articles.snippet: At Hewlett-Packard, a new chief executive has taken the company in a different direction, and not everyone is pleased.
articles.abstract: At Hewlett-Packard, a new chief executive has taken the company in a different direction, and not everyone is pleased.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much does a chief executive really matter at a multibillion-dollar technology company? Apple’s employees, customers, shareholders, board and Steve Jobs’s successor, Tim Cook, must hope the answer turns out to be a lot different than at the world’s largest computer company, neighboring Hewlett-Packard.

articles.headline: Investment Advice for Doctors: First, Do No Harm
articles.snippet: They take eight or so years off from the world to do nothing but learn how to be doctors, then receive a six-figure annual paycheck with no real idea of what to do with it.
articles.abstract: They take eight or so years off from the world to do nothing but learn how to be doctors, then receive a six-figure annual paycheck with no real idea of what to do with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nobody’s perfect, but some types of people are much less perfect with their money than others.

articles.headline: The Plastic Sandwich Bag Flunks
articles.snippet: Retailers and schools are promoting waste-free options for packing lunch, but parents have been a bit slow to embrace the idea.
articles.abstract: Retailers and schools are promoting waste-free options for packing lunch, but parents have been a bit slow to embrace the idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many retailers and schools are advocating waste-free options for back-to-school shoppers this year, especially when it comes to lunch. School lists call for Tupperware instead of Ziplocs, neoprene lunch bags instead of brown paper ones, and aluminum water bottles, not the throwaway plastic versions.

articles.headline: Case of 8,000 Menacing Posts Tests Limits of Twitter Speech
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. says William Cassidy published 8,000 Twitter posts, almost all of them about a woman, Alyce Zeoli, and her Buddhist group.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. says William Cassidy published 8,000 Twitter posts, almost all of them about a woman, Alyce Zeoli, and her Buddhist group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even the Buddha of compassion might have been distressed to be on the receiving end of the diatribes that William Lawrence Cassidy is accused of posting on Twitter.

articles.headline: As Trade Volumes Soar, Exchanges Cash In
articles.snippet: The latest trading rush is enhancing exchanges’ bottom line, but some analysts worry that the volatility and downbeat economic news may frighten away investors in the long term.
articles.abstract: The latest trading rush is enhancing exchanges’ bottom line, but some analysts worry that the volatility and downbeat economic news may frighten away investors in the long term.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest financial market convulsions have been tough for almost everyone, including traders caught on the wrong side of another big swing and pained everyday investors watching their dwindling holdings go down and up — and down again.

articles.headline: South African Goes From Never a Sip to Vineyard Fame
articles.snippet: Ntsiki Biyela left her village in Zululand to become one of South Africa’s few black winemakers in a white-dominated industry, accumulating awards along the way.
articles.abstract: Ntsiki Biyela left her village in Zululand to become one of South Africa’s few black winemakers in a white-dominated industry, accumulating awards along the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa — When Ntsiki Biyela won a winemaking scholarship in 1998, she was certainly a curious choice. She had grown up in the undulating hills of Zululand, living in a small village of huts and shacks. People tended their patches of pumpkins and corn. The only alcohol they drank was homemade beer, a malt-fed brew that bubbled in old pots.

articles.headline: Damage and Flooding Scar Atlantic Seaboard
articles.snippet: A weakened but still ferocious Hurricane Irene began its gradual, destructive move up the East Coast, contributing to the deaths of at least nine people.
articles.abstract: A weakened but still ferocious Hurricane Irene began its gradual, destructive move up the East Coast, contributing to the deaths of at least nine people.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by   Kim Severson,  Dan Barry and  Campbell Robertson and was written by Mr. Barry.
articles.byline: By Kim Severson, Dan Barry and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Ingredients of Shady Origins, Posing as Supplements
articles.snippet: Drugs marketed in the guise of supplements may contain dangerous amphetamines, synthetic steroids, laxatives and other prohibited compounds.
articles.abstract: Drugs marketed in the guise of supplements may contain dangerous amphetamines, synthetic steroids, laxatives and other prohibited compounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON

articles.headline: The Changing Face of the Burning Man Festival
articles.snippet: As an annual counterculture arts festival in the Nevada desert gears up for its opening, debates about the organization’s transition to a nonprofit are simmering.
articles.abstract: As an annual counterculture arts festival in the Nevada desert gears up for its opening, debates about the organization’s transition to a nonprofit are simmering.
articles.lead_paragraph: TENS of thousands of volunteers are gathering to build a city in a Nevada desert that is notorious for triple-digit temperatures, high winds and blinding plumes of dust.

articles.headline: The Rescue That Missed Main Street
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve lent billions to rescue banks during the financial crisis, but it has done little to help American taxpayers.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve lent billions to rescue banks during the financial crisis, but it has done little to help American taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR the last three years we have been told repeatedly by government officials that funneling hundreds of billions of dollars to large and teetering banks during the credit crisis was necessary to save the financial system, and beneficial to Main Street.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Drone Is Said to Kill Al Qaeda’s No. 2
articles.snippet: An American official said that a strike by the Central Intelligence Agency on Aug. 22 killed Atiyah Abd al-Rahman, a Libyan who in the last year had taken over as Al Qaeda’s top operational planner.
articles.abstract: An American official said that a strike by the Central Intelligence Agency on Aug. 22 killed Atiyah Abd al-Rahman, a Libyan who in the last year had taken over as Al Qaeda’s top operational planner.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A drone operated by the Central Intelligence Agency killed Al Qaeda’s second-ranking figure in the mountains of Pakistan on Monday, American and Pakistani officials said Saturday, further damaging a terrorism network that appears significantly weakened since the death of Osama bin Laden in May.

articles.headline: A Lone Oklahoma Tower’s Clear but Uncomfortable Links to 9/11
articles.snippet: As the twin towers came under attack, employees of an energy firm in a sister tower in Tulsa were taking messages from doomed traders at the World Trade Center.
articles.abstract: As the twin towers came under attack, employees of an energy firm in a sister tower in Tulsa were taking messages from doomed traders at the World Trade Center.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — The phones rattled with the sound of an explosion. It was Sept. 11, and some of the traders at an energy company here had been speaking with colleagues at a financial company in the World Trade Center in New York. Suddenly, routine business calls became frantic dictations of final messages to loved ones. Then the lines went dead.

articles.headline: Lines Blur Between Candidates and PACs With Unlimited Cash
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court ruling paved the way for supporters to raise unlimited cash for presidential contenders.
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court ruling paved the way for supporters to raise unlimited cash for presidential contenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: One night last month, Mitt Romney strode into a dining room above Central Park that was packed with dozens of his wealthiest supporters, gathered there by a group of former campaign aides, to talk about his bid for the White House.

articles.headline: Steve Jobs Reigned in a Kingdom of Altered Landscapes
articles.snippet: Again and again, Steve Jobs would step up to entrenched players in media and explain their business to them in ways they didn’t recognize from the inside.
articles.abstract: Again and again, Steve Jobs would step up to entrenched players in media and explain their business to them in ways they didn’t recognize from the inside.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, I wrote a column about the publishing industry’s resistance to the terms Apple was imposing for subscriptions on the iPad. Soon after, an e-mail was followed by a phone call and Steve Jobs was on the line to straighten me out.

articles.headline: Gilded Traces of the Lives Qaddafis Led
articles.snippet: The mansions, farms and seaside villas of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family are revealing the details of lives lived far removed from the people.
articles.abstract: The mansions, farms and seaside villas of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family are revealing the details of lives lived far removed from the people.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — His name of choice was the Brother Leader, though his nearly 42 years of rule were rarely brotherly, and his leadership left a country with plentiful oil in shambles.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Prime Time Ambitions
articles.snippet: Sony’s television business — rebuilt brick by brick, or at least time slot by time slot — is now driving profitability at Sony Pictures Entertainment.
articles.abstract: Sony’s television business — rebuilt brick by brick, or at least time slot by time slot — is now driving profitability at Sony Pictures Entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — In October 2001, an exasperated Howard Stringer, the chief executive of Sony, ordered a substantial downsizing at the company’s studio here.

articles.headline: Irene Adds to a Bad Year for Insurance Industry
articles.snippet: Most of the estimated $7 billion in losses from Hurricane Irene will very likely come from property in New York and New Jersey, according to industry experts.
articles.abstract: Most of the estimated $7 billion in losses from Hurricane Irene will very likely come from property in New York and New Jersey, according to industry experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The total damage inflicted by Hurricane Irene may reach $7 billion by the time the storm dissipates in the coming days, making one of the insurance industry’s worst years even tougher, according to an early estimate by the Kinetic Analysis Corporation in Silver Spring, Md.

articles.headline: Profits Falling, Banks Confront a Leaner Future
articles.snippet: Banks are finding their growth constrained, even as they add new costs for consumers.
articles.abstract: Banks are finding their growth constrained, even as they add new costs for consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Battered by a weak economy, the nation’s biggest banks are cutting jobs, consolidating businesses and scrambling for new sources of income in anticipation of a fundamentally altered financial landscape requiring leaner operations.

articles.headline: A Warning for Some, Entertainment for Others
articles.snippet: Delivering on its promise to take people into the path of hurricanes makes the Weather Channel a must for viewers, who tune in to see storm coverage and wind-battered reporters.
articles.abstract: Delivering on its promise to take people into the path of hurricanes makes the Weather Channel a must for viewers, who tune in to see storm coverage and wind-battered reporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAGS HEAD, N.C. — Standing where he warned others not to tread, the beach on the Outer Banks during Hurricane Irene’s landfall, Mike Seidel had sand in his teeth, his pockets and his ears. He was soaking wet, barely able to hear — and he was beaming.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Scion Tackles Hollywood
articles.snippet: Megan Ellison, 25, is providing financial backing to many people who make the sophisticated dramas and adventure films that are too risky for studios and their corporate owners.
articles.abstract: Megan Ellison, 25, is providing financial backing to many people who make the sophisticated dramas and adventure films that are too risky for studios and their corporate owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Annapurna, a Hindu goddess of nourishment, has her name on a section of the Himalayas. Annapurna Pictures operates from a cluster of three multimillion-dollar homes in the Hollywood Hills.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Police Lineups Start to Face Fact: Eyes Can Lie
articles.snippet: A decision by New Jersey’s Supreme Court last week could help change the way police officers get witnesses to identify suspects.
articles.abstract: A decision by New Jersey’s Supreme Court last week could help change the way police officers get witnesses to identify suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decision by New Jersey’s Supreme Court last week to overhaul the state’s rules for how judges and jurors treat evidence from police lineups could help transform the way officers conduct a central technique of police work, criminal justice experts say.
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and John Schwartz

articles.headline: As a States’ Rights Stalwart, Perry Draws Doubts
articles.snippet: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has come to publicly embrace states’ rights as a defining issue only in the past few years.
articles.abstract: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has come to publicly embrace states’ rights as a defining issue only in the past few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — As Gov. Rick Perry of Texas begins his presidential campaign, he is working hard to position himself as the leading Republican champion of states’ rights, using his high-profile battles with Washington and his book on the dangers of federal power to build an ideological and constitutional rationale for his fierce anti-Obama message.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Emily Ramshaw

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Wife and 3 of His Children Flee to Algeria
articles.snippet: A report was the first official news on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s family since he was routed from Tripoli.
articles.abstract: A report was the first official news on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s family since he was routed from Tripoli.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Algeria said Monday that it had allowed a two-vehicle caravan of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s relatives, including his second wife and three of his children, into the country. The flight of his relatives provided powerful new evidence of surrender by the Qaddafi clan as rebels consolidated their hold on Tripoli, the capital.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Economic Adviser Pick Is Known as Labor Expert
articles.snippet: President Obama nominated Alan B. Krueger, an economist on the job market.
articles.abstract: President Obama nominated Alan B. Krueger, an economist on the job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In tapping Alan B. Krueger on Monday to lead the Council of Economic Advisers, President Obama has picked an economist well known for his studies of labor markets just as the president is about to announce a renewed push for job creation policies as early as next week.

articles.headline: Storm’s Push North Leaves Punishing Inland Floods
articles.snippet: Communities in Vermont and upstate New York dug out from under debris, and houses were swept away.
articles.abstract: Communities in Vermont and upstate New York dug out from under debris, and houses were swept away.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHESTER, Vt. — While most eyes warily watched the shoreline during Hurricane Irene’s grinding ride up the East Coast, it was inland — sometimes hundreds of miles inland — where the most serious damage actually occurred. And the major culprit was not wind, but water.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Danny Hakim
